Notation:
(⌞)(\llcorner)(└) means lower-triangular matrices (or the set of them).
(⌝)(\urcorner)(┐) means upper-triangulars.
(╲)(\diagdown)(╲) means diagonal matrices.
∝≈\underset{\approx}{\propto}≈∝​ means “approximately/asymptotically proportional to.”

Gaussian Elimination and LU Factorization

Big idea: the LU factorized a matrix into an upper- (U) and a lower-triangular (L) matrix. The Gaussian Elimination turns the matrix into U, and those operations are represented by L.

Vanilla Gaussian Elimination and LU

  • Given a linear system Ax=bAx=bAx=b, where A∈Rn×nA \in \mathbb{R}^{n\times n}A∈Rn×n, we can eliminate the entries under the diagonal via elementary row operations. In particular, in eliminating entries under the aiia_{ii}aii​ element, it is substracting multiples of the iiith row from the rows beneath it. AundefinedERO[××⋯××⋯××⋯××⋯×]undefinedERO[×  ××⋯×       ××⋯××⋯××⋯×]undefinedERO⋯A \xrightarrow{\text{ERO}}\left[\begin{array}{c|c} \times & \times \dots \times \\ & \times \dots \times \\ & \times \dots \times \\ & \times \dots \times \end{array}\right] \xrightarrow{\text{ERO}} \left[\begin{array}{c|c} \times \,\, \times & \times \dots \times \\ \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\times & \times \dots \times \\ & \times \dots \times \\ & \times \dots \times \end{array}\right]\xrightarrow{\text{ERO}}\cdotsAERO​⎣⎡​×​×⋯××⋯××⋯××⋯×​⎦⎤​ERO​⎣⎡​×××​×⋯××⋯××⋯××⋯×​⎦⎤​ERO​⋯
  • These EROs can be represented by pre-multiplication with lower triangular matrices: subtracting λ⋅rowi\lambda \cdot \mathrm{row}_{i}λ⋅rowi​ from rowj\mathrm{row}_{j}rowj​ corresponds to the matrix M(i,j,λ)=In×n−λ(δij)n×n∈(⌞)M(i,j,\lambda)=I_{n\times n}-\lambda(\delta_{ij})_{n \times n}\in (\llcorner)M(i,j,λ)=In×n​−λ(δij​)n×n​∈(└)i.e. the identity matrix, except with a −λ-\lambda−λ in the (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) entry. It’s lower-triangular because i<ji < ji<j in Gaussian elimination.
  • Reducing the whole iiith column under the diagonal is then represented by the matrix Li≡∏j=i+1nM(i,j,−aijaii)=(1⋱1−a(j+1)iaii1⋮⋱−aniaii1)L_{i} \equiv\prod^{n}_{j=i+1}M\left( i,j, -\frac{a_{ij}}{a_{ii}} \right)=\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ & \ddots \\ & & 1 \\ & & - \frac{a_{(j+1)i}}{a_{ii}} & 1 \\ & & \vdots & & & \ddots \\ & & - \frac{a_{ni}}{a_{ii}} & & & & 1 \end{pmatrix}Li​≡j=i+1∏n​M(i,j,−aii​aij​​)=⎝⎛​1​⋱​1−aii​a(j+1)i​​⋮−aii​ani​​​1​​⋱​1​⎠⎞​
  • Reducing the entire matrix AAA becomes the matrix product Ln⋯L1A=UL_{n}\cdots L_{1}A=ULn​⋯L1​A=Uand since the product Ln⋯L1∈(⌞)L_{n}\cdots L_{1} \in (\llcorner)Ln​⋯L1​∈(└) is invertible (diagonal elements are all 111). Hence denoting the inverse as L=(Ln⋯L1)−1L=(L_{n}\cdots L_{1})^{-1}L=(Ln​⋯L1​)−1, the LU factorization of AAA is A=LU=(⌞)(⌝)A=LU=(\llcorner)(\urcorner)A=LU=(└)(┐)

Pivoting

Big idea: (partial) pivoting improves the stability of vanilla GE by permuting the rows of AAA with permutation matrix PPP. The factorization is LU=PALU=PALU=PA.

  • In Gaussian elimination a pivot is used to eliminate the entries below it; in vanilla GE, they are the diagonal entries aiia_{ii}aii​.
  • Naively using the diagonal as pivots cause issues:
    • When aii=0a_{ii} = 0aii​=0, the quotients −aij/aiii-a_{ij} / a_{iii}−aij​/aiii​ are not well-defined.
    • If ∣aii∣≠0|a_{ii}| \ne 0∣aii​∣=0 are tiny, the quotients would be huge, making the computation unstable.
    • Hence the larger the pivot the better.
  • Pivoting is a solution to the issue: when eliminating the iiith column, it looks for a larger entry in the “remainder” of the matrix, and swaps it with aiia_{ii}aii​ by exchanging their rows and/or columns:
    [×××……×××……×aii………………a∗∗…search here]undefinedpivot[×××……×××……×a∗∗………………aii…]\left[\begin{array}{} \times & \times & \begin{matrix}\times & \dots & \dots & \times\end{matrix} \\ & \times & \begin{matrix} \times & \dots & \dots & \times \end{matrix} \\ & & \underset{\text{search here}}{\boxed{\begin{matrix} a_{ii} & \dots & \dots \\ \dots & \dots & \dots \\ \dots & a_{**} & \dots \\ \end{matrix}}} \\ \end{array}\right] \xrightarrow{\text{pivot}} \left[\begin{array}{} \times & \times & \begin{matrix}\times & \dots & \dots & \times\end{matrix} \\ & \times & \begin{matrix} \times & \dots & \dots & \times \end{matrix} \\ & & \boxed{\begin{matrix} a_{**} & \dots & \dots \\ \dots & \dots & \dots \\ \dots & a_{ii} & \dots \\ \end{matrix}} \\ \end{array}\right]⎣⎡​×​××​×​…​…​×​×​…​…​×​search hereaii​……​……a∗∗​​………​​​​⎦⎤​pivot​⎣⎡​×​××​×​…​…​×​×​…​…​×​a∗∗​……​……aii​​………​​​⎦⎤​
  • Ideally, the swap should get the largest element in the entire “remainder”, but searching over a (n−i)×(n−i)(n-i)\times(n-i)(n−i)×(n−i) matrix at each step is computationally expensive.
  • Partial pivoting is a compromise by restricting pivoting to elements in the same column: if ai∗=max⁡j{aij}a_{i*}=\max_{j}\{ a_{ij} \}ai∗​=maxj​{aij​}, partial pivot exchanges the rows to get
    [×××…×××…×aii…ai∗here…×…×…×]undefinedpartial pivot[×××…×××…×ai∗…aii…×…×…×]\left[\begin{array}{} \times & \times & \times & \begin{matrix} \dots & \times\end{matrix} \\ & \times & \times & \begin{matrix} \dots & \times \end{matrix} \\ & & \underset{\text{here}}{\boxed{\begin{matrix} a_{ii} \\ \dots \\ a_{i*} \\ \end{matrix}}} & \begin{matrix} \dots & \times \\ \dots & \times \\ \dots & \times \\ \end{matrix} \end{array}\right] \xrightarrow{\text{partial pivot}} \left[\begin{array}{} \times & \times & \times & \begin{matrix} \dots & \times\end{matrix} \\ & \times & \times & \begin{matrix} \dots & \times \end{matrix} \\ & & \boxed{\begin{matrix} a_{i*} \\ \dots \\ a_{ii} \\ \end{matrix}} & \begin{matrix} \dots & \times \\ \dots & \times \\ \dots & \times \\ \end{matrix} \end{array}\right]⎣⎡​×​××​××hereaii​…ai∗​​​​​…​×​…​×​………​×××​​⎦⎤​partial pivot​⎣⎡​×​××​××ai∗​…aii​​​​…​×​…​×​………​×××​​⎦⎤​
  • Hence at each step, GE with partial pivoting performs (1) an exchange of rows, and (2) elimination: [ aii…aik……  ……  ……  ]AundefinedPpartial pivot[ aik…aii……  ……  ……  ]PAundefinedLGE[aik……0……0……]LPA \underset{A}{\left[ \begin{array}{} {\, \boxed{\begin{matrix}a_{ii} \\\dots \\ a_{ik}\\\end{matrix}}} & \begin{matrix} \dots & \dots\,\, \\ \dots & \dots\,\, \\ \dots & \dots\,\, \end{matrix} \end{array} \right]} \xrightarrow[P]{\text{partial pivot}} \underset{PA}{\left[ \begin{array}{} {\, \boxed{\begin{matrix}a_{ik} \\\dots \\ a_{ii}\\\end{matrix}}} & \begin{matrix} \dots & \dots\,\, \\ \dots & \dots\,\, \\ \dots & \dots\,\, \end{matrix} \end{array} \right]} \xrightarrow[L]{\text{GE}} \underset{LPA}{\begin{bmatrix} a_{ik} & \dots & \dots \\ 0 & \dots & \dots \\ 0 & \dots & \dots \end{bmatrix}}A⎣⎡​aii​…aik​​​​………​………​​⎦⎤​​partial pivotP​PA⎣⎡​aik​…aii​​​​………​………​​⎦⎤​​GEL​LPA⎣⎡​aik​00​………​………​⎦⎤​​or as matrix multiplications, A↦LiPiAA \mapsto L_{i}P_{i}AA↦Li​Pi​A, where PiP_{i}Pi​ is the permutation matrix that performs the partial pivoting (i.e. exchanging the iiith and kkkth rows).
  • The entire elimination process is then LnPn⋯L1P1A=UL_{n}P_{n}\cdots L_{1}P_{1}A = ULn​Pn​⋯L1​P1​A=Ubut note that commuting a lower-triangular matrix with a permutation gives another lower triangular matrix: PL=L′P,   where L′=PLP−1∈(⌞)PL=L'P,\,\,\text{ where }L'=PLP^{-1} \in (\llcorner)PL=L′P, where L′=PLP−1∈(└)so moving all the permutation matrices to the left of LkL_{k}Lk​, (Ln′⋯L1′)undefinedL−1Pn⋯P1undefinedPA=U\underbrace{(L'_{n}\cdots L'_{1})}_{L ^{-1}}\underbrace{P_{n}\cdots P_{1}}_{P }A=UL−1(Ln′​⋯L1′​)​​PPn​⋯P1​​​A=Uand inverting L−1L^{-1}L−1 gives LU=PALU=PALU=PAthe LU factorization of PAPAPA.

Singular Value Decomposition

Big idea: the SVD is a matrix decomposition into a orthonormal-diagonal-orthogonal product; it exists for all matrices, including non-square ones.

  • Given a matrix A∈Rm×nA \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n}A∈Rm×n, m≥nm \ge nm≥n, there are orthogonal bases V={v1,…,vn}⊂Rn\mathcal{V}=\{ v_{1},\dots,v_{n} \} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}V={v1​,…,vn​}⊂Rn and U={u1,…,um}⊂Rm\mathcal{U}=\{ u_{1},\dots,u_{m} \} \subset \mathbb{R}^{m}U={u1​,…,um​}⊂Rm such that VundefinedA{σ1u1,…,σnun} \mathcal{V} \xrightarrow{A}\{ \sigma_{1}u_{1},\dots,\sigma_{n}u_{n} \}VA​{σ1​u1​,…,σn​un​}
  • The factors σ1,…,σn\sigma_{1},\dots,\sigma_{n}σ1​,…,σn​ are the singular values of AAA; they can be non-distinct, but are usually arranged in descending order (both as a list and in the matrix).
  • In matrix form, let VVV be the matrix with columns from V\mathcal{V}V, U^\hat{U}U^ the matrix with columns being the first mmm elements of U\mathcal{U}U, and Σ^=diag(σ1,…,σn)\hat{\Sigma}=\mathrm{diag}(\sigma_{1},\dots,\sigma_{n})Σ^=diag(σ1​,…,σn​): AV=U^Σ^AV=\hat{U}\hat{\Sigma}AV=U^Σ^
  • Since V\mathcal{V}V are chosen to be orthogonal, right-apply the inverse VT{V}^{T}VT gives the singular value decomposition of AAA: A=U^ΣVTA=\hat{U}\Sigma V^{T}A=U^ΣVT

Forms of the SVD

  • As V\mathcal{V}V is only mapped into the first mmm elements of U\mathcal{U}U, the above expression omitted the other vectors of U\mathcal{U}U; it is called the thin/reduced SVD: Am×n=[↑↑u1…un↓↓]m×n[σ11⋱σnn]n×n[⟵v1⟶⋮⟵vn⟶]n×nA_{m \times n}=\begin{bmatrix} \Bigg\uparrow & &\Bigg\uparrow \\ u_{1} & \dots & u_{n} \\ \Bigg\downarrow & & \Bigg\downarrow \end{bmatrix}_{m \times n} \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_{11} \\ & \ddots \\ & & \sigma_{nn} \end{bmatrix}_{n\times n} \begin{bmatrix} \longleftarrow & v_{1} & \longrightarrow \\ & \vdots \\ \longleftarrow & v_{n} & \longrightarrow \end{bmatrix}_{n\times n}Am×n​=⎣⎡​⏐↑​u1​↓⏐​​…​⏐↑​un​↓⏐​​⎦⎤​m×n​⎣⎡​σ11​​⋱​σnn​​⎦⎤​n×n​⎣⎡​⟵⟵​v1​⋮vn​​⟶⟶​⎦⎤​n×n​
  • The full SVD includes the additional vectors of U\mathcal{U}U, and extra zero rows in Σ\SigmaΣ to preserve the product: Am×n=[↑↑u1……um↓↓]m×m[σ11⋱σnn]m×n[⟵v1⟶⋮⟵vn⟶]n×nA_{m \times n}=\begin{bmatrix} \Bigg\uparrow & &\Bigg\uparrow \\ u_{1} & \dots \dots & u_{m} \\ \Bigg\downarrow & & \Bigg\downarrow \end{bmatrix}_{m \times m} \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_{11} \\ & \ddots \\ & & \sigma_{nn} \\ \\ \\ \end{bmatrix}_{m\times n} \begin{bmatrix} \longleftarrow & v_{1} & \longrightarrow \\ & \vdots \\ \longleftarrow & v_{n} & \longrightarrow \end{bmatrix}_{n\times n}Am×n​=⎣⎡​⏐↑​u1​↓⏐​​……​⏐↑​um​↓⏐​​⎦⎤​m×m​⎣⎡​σ11​​⋱​σnn​​⎦⎤​m×n​⎣⎡​⟵⟵​v1​⋮vn​​⟶⟶​⎦⎤​n×n​and these full matrices are denoted A=UΣVTA=U\Sigma V^{T}A=UΣVT (without the hats).
  • In general for complex matrices, the singular value decomposition of A∈Cm×nA \in \mathbb{C}^{m\times n}A∈Cm×n is the product A=UΣV∗A=U\Sigma V^{*}A=UΣV∗where U,VU,VU,V are unitary, and Σ\SigmaΣ diagonal, with non-increasing entries.

Proofs of Existence

  • The SVD of AAA is closely related to ATAA^{T}AATA, which is symmetric and positive definite. Hence all its eigenvalues are non-negative.

Proof: symmetry is immediate.
positive-definiteness: for any v∈Rnv \in \mathbb{R}^{n}v∈Rn, vT(ATA)v=∥Av∥2≥0v^{T}(A^{T}A)v=\|Av\|^{2} \ge 0vT(ATA)v=∥Av∥2≥0.
non-negativity: for any eigenvalue λ\lambdaλ with eigenvector vvv, 0≤vT(ATA)v=vTλv=λ∥v∥20 \le v^{T} (A^{T}A)v=v^{T}\lambda v=\lambda\|v\|^{2}0≤vT(ATA)v=vTλv=λ∥v∥2, so λ\lambdaλ must be non-negative.

  • Hence by the spectral theorem, it can be diagonalized as ATA=VCVT=VD2VTA^{T}A=VCV^{T}=VD^{2}V^{T}ATA=VCVT=VD2VTwhere VVV is the orthogonal basis containing the eigenvectors of ATAA^{T }AATA, and C=D2C=D^{2}C=D2 containing the eigenvalues is well-defined since the eigenvalues are non-negative.

  • If rank(A)≡r=n\mathrm{rank}(A)\equiv r=nrank(A)≡r=n, then the thin SVD exists.

Proof: consider ATA=VD2VTA^{T}A=VD^{2}V^{T}ATA=VD2VT.
Since AAA is full-ranked, DDD contains no zeros in the diagonal, hence it can be inverted to give U^≡AVD−1\hat{U} \equiv AVD^{-1}U^≡AVD−1, which is orthogonal. Hence A=U^DVTA=\hat{U}DV^{T}A=U^DVTis the thin SVD.

  • In general, let rank(A)=r≤n\mathrm{rank}(A)=r \le nrank(A)=r≤n, and its thin SVD exists.

Proof: in this case DDD is not invertible; we will invert part of it instead. Denote B=AVB=AVB=AV so that BTB=D2B^{T}B=D^{2}BTB=D2, and B,DB,DB,D are of the form D=[Dr0n−r], B=[↑↑↑↑b1…br0…0↓↓↓↓]D=\begin{bmatrix} D_{r} & \\ & 0_{n-r} \end{bmatrix},\, B=\begin{bmatrix} \Bigg\uparrow & &\Bigg\uparrow &\Bigg\uparrow & &\Bigg\uparrow \\ b_{1} & \dots & b_{r} & 0 & \dots & 0 \\ \Bigg\downarrow & & \Bigg\downarrow & \Bigg\downarrow & & \Bigg\downarrow \end{bmatrix}D=[Dr​​0n−r​​],B=⎣⎡​⏐↑​b1​↓⏐​​…​⏐↑​br​↓⏐​​⏐↑​0↓⏐​​…​⏐↑​0↓⏐​​⎦⎤​where DrD_{r}Dr​ contains the non-zero entries; the last columns of BBB are zero since the diagonal elements in BTB=DB^{T}B=DBTB=D are their magnitudes, the last few of which are zeros.
We can then invert DrD_{r}Dr​ to get [U^10]=B[Dr−1In−r]\begin{bmatrix}\hat{U}_{1} & 0\end{bmatrix}=B \begin{bmatrix}D_{r}^{-1} & \\ & I_{n-r}\end{bmatrix}[U^1​​0​]=B[Dr−1​​In−r​​]. Hence A=[U^10][DrIn−r]VTA=\begin{bmatrix}\hat{U}_{1} & 0\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}D_{r} & \\ & I_{n-r}\end{bmatrix}V^{T}A=[U^1​​0​][Dr​​In−r​​]VT
Filling the zeros by extending U^1\hat{U}_{1}U^1​ by (n−r)(n-r)(n−r) elements to an orthonormal U^=[U^1U^2]\hat{U}=\begin{bmatrix}\hat{U}_{1}&\hat{U}_{2}\end{bmatrix}U^=[U^1​​U^2​​] and changing the diagonal entries in to zero to preserve the product gives A=U^[Dr0n−r]undefinedΣ^VTA=\hat{U}\underbrace{\begin{bmatrix}D_{r} & \\ & 0_{n-r}\end{bmatrix}}_{\hat{\Sigma}}V^{T}A=U^Σ^[Dr​​0n−r​​]​​VT

  • Given the thin SVD of a matrix A=U^Σ^VTA=\hat{U}\hat{\Sigma}V^{T}A=U^Σ^VT, any extension of U^\hat{U}U^ to an nnn-element orthogonal basis of Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn gives the full SVD.

Proof: it’s straightforward to see that if UUU is the extension of U^\hat{U}U^, and U^⊥\hat{U}_{\perp}U^⊥​ is the matrix containing the extra vectors, then A=U^Σ^VT=[U^U^⊥][1^12]undefinedU[Σ^0(m−n)×n]undefinedΣVTA=\hat{U}\hat{\Sigma}V^{T}= \underbrace{\begin{bmatrix}\hat{U} & \hat{U}_{\perp}\end{bmatrix}\vphantom{\begin{bmatrix}\hat{1}\\1_{2}\end{bmatrix}}}_{U} \underbrace{\begin{bmatrix}\hat{\Sigma} \\ 0_{(m-n)\times n}\end{bmatrix}}_{\Sigma}V^{T}A=U^Σ^VT=U[U^​U^⊥​​][1^12​​]​​Σ[Σ^0(m−n)×n​​]​​VTis a full SVD.

SVD as Low-Rank Approximations

  • Written in vector/column forms, where U^=[u1,…,ur]\hat{U}=[u_{1},\dots,u_{r}]U^=[u1​,…,ur​] and V^=[v1,…,vr]\hat{V}=[v_{1},\dots,v_{r}]V^=[v1​,…,vr​], the SVD is equivalent to A=∑i=1ruiσiviTA=\sum_{i=1}^{r}u_{i}\sigma_{i}v_{i}^{T}A=i=1∑r​ui​σi​viT​where each term is a rank-1 m×nm \times nm×n matrix; its contribution is determined by σi\sigma_{i}σi​.
  • The truncated SVD AkA_{k}Ak​ are rank-kkk approximations of AAA, where k≤rk \le rk≤r: Ak=∑i=1kuiσiviTA_{k}=\sum_{i=1}^{k}u_{i}\sigma_{i}v^{T}_{i}Ak​=i=1∑k​ui​σi​viT​assuming σ1,…,n\sigma_{1,\dots, n}σ1,…,n​ are non-increasing.
  • In fact, this is the best rank-kkk approximation. To define the error between AAA and an approximation, the spectral norm or the 2-norm of any matrix B∈Rm×nB \in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}B∈Rm×n is ∥B∥2≡max⁡x≠0∥Bx∥∥x∥=largest singular value of B\|B\|_{2}\equiv \max_{x \ne \mathbf{0}} \frac{\|Bx\|}{\|x\|}=\text{largest singular value of }B∥B∥2​≡x=0max​∥x∥∥Bx∥​=largest singular value of Bwhere ∥x∥\|x\|∥x∥ is the Euclidean norm of vectors.
  • Then under the spectral norm, the truncated SVD is the best approximation: for any B∈Rm×nB \in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}B∈Rm×n with rank(B)≤k\mathrm{rank}(B) \le krank(B)≤k, ∥A−Ak∥2=σk+1≤∥A−B∥2\|A-A_{k}\|_{2}=\sigma_{k+1} \le \|A-B\|_{2}∥A−Ak​∥2​=σk+1​≤∥A−B∥2​

Proof: the equality is immediate.
For the inequality, suppose for contradiction that there is B:∥A−B∥2<σk+1B:\|A-B\|_{2} < \sigma_{k+1}B:∥A−B∥2​<σk+1​. Then rank(B)≤k\mathrm{rank}(B) \le krank(B)≤k means that there is a subspace W≤ker⁡B:dim⁡(W)=n−kW \le \ker B:\dim(W)=n-kW≤kerB:dim(W)=n−k. So for any w∈Ww \in Ww∈W, ∥Aw∥2=∥(A−B)w∥2≤∥A−B∥2∥w∥<σk+1∥w∥\|Aw\|_{2}=\|(A-B)w\|_{2} \le \|A-B\|_{2}\|w\|<\sigma_{k+1}\|w\|∥Aw∥2​=∥(A−B)w∥2​≤∥A−B∥2​∥w∥<σk+1​∥w∥Hence WWW is disjoint with Vk=⟨v1,…,vk⟩V_{k}=\langle v_{1},\dots,v_{k} \rangleVk​=⟨v1​,…,vk​⟩, as ∥Av∥2≥σk≥σk+1\|Av\|_{2} \ge \sigma_{k}\ge \sigma_{k+1}∥Av∥2​≥σk​≥σk+1​ for any v∈Vkv \in V_{k}v∈Vk​.
But this means that there are disjoint subspaces with dimensions n−kn-kn−k and n+1n+1n+1 in Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn, a contradiction.

  • In terms of information, the truncated SVD is the low-rank matrix that best summarizes the information in AAA.
    • If AAA is an image, the truncated SVD compresses a high-rank image matrix into a few vector products.
    • If AAA is data with rows being individual samples and columns being a few specs measured on the sample, the truncated SVD finds linear combinations of the specs (principal components) that are the most “interesting”.

QR Factorization

  • QR factorization decomposes a matrix A∈Rm×n,m≥nA \in \mathbb{R}^{m \times n},m \ge nA∈Rm×n,m≥n into the product of an orthogonal/orthonormal matrix QQQ and an upper-triangular RRR.
  • The thin/reduced QR factorization produces a “thin” orthonormal Q^m×n\hat{Q}_{m \times n}Q^​m×n​ and a “small” R^n×n\hat{ R}_{n \times n}R^n×n​: Am×n=[↑↑q1…qn↓↓]m×n[r11…r1n⋱⋮rnn]n×nA_{m \times n}=\begin{bmatrix} \Bigg\uparrow & &\Bigg\uparrow \\ q_{1} & \dots & q_{n} \\ \Bigg\downarrow & & \Bigg\downarrow \end{bmatrix}_{m \times n} \begin{bmatrix} r_{11} & \dots & r_{1n}\\ & \ddots & \vdots\\ & & r_{nn} \end{bmatrix}_{n\times n}Am×n​=⎣⎡​⏐↑​q1​↓⏐​​…​⏐↑​qn​↓⏐​​⎦⎤​m×n​⎣⎡​r11​​…⋱​r1n​⋮rnn​​⎦⎤​n×n​in this case Q^\hat{Q}Q^​ is not orthogonal, as Q^Q^T≠Im\hat{Q}\hat{Q}^{T}\ne I_{m}Q^​Q^​T=Im​.
  • The full QR factorization produces a “full” orthogonal Qm×mQ_{m \times m}Qm×m​ and a “large” Rm×nR_{m \times n}Rm×n​: Am×n=[↑↑q1…qn↓↓↑↑qn+1…qm↓↓]m×m[r11…r1n⋱⋮rnn]m×nA_{m \times n}=\left[\begin{array}{c|c} \begin{array}{c c}\Bigg\uparrow & &\Bigg\uparrow \\q_{1} & \dots & q_{n} \\\Bigg\downarrow & & \Bigg\downarrow\end{array} & \begin{array}{c c}\Bigg\uparrow & &\Bigg\uparrow \\ q_{n+1} & \dots & q_{m} \\\Bigg\downarrow & & \Bigg\downarrow\end{array} \end{array}\right] _{m \times m} \begin{bmatrix} r_{11} & \dots & r_{1n}\\ & \ddots & \vdots\\ & & r_{nn} \\ \\ \\ \end{bmatrix}_{m\times n}Am×n​=⎣⎡​⏐↑​q1​↓⏐​​…​⏐↑​qn​↓⏐​​​⏐↑​qn+1​↓⏐​​…​⏐↑​qm​↓⏐​​​⎦⎤​m×m​⎣⎡​r11​​…⋱​r1n​⋮rnn​​⎦⎤​m×n​where QQQ is orthogonal: QTQ=QQT=ImQ^{T}Q=QQ^{T}=I_{m}QTQ=QQT=Im​. Although QQQ has additional columns, they only multiply with the additional zero rows in RRR, so they have no effect on the product.

QR with Gram-Schmidt

Big idea: Gram-Schmidt on AAA makes it orthogonal via multiplication with an upper-triangular matrix.

  • Recall that the Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization process can generates an orthonormal set, given a set of independent vectors: {u1,…,un} independentundefinedG-S{v1,…,vn} orthonormal\{ u_{1},\dots,u_{n} \} \text{ independent} \xmapsto{\text{G-S}}\{ v_{1},\dots,v_{n} \}\text{ orthonormal}{u1​,…,un​} independentG-S​{v1​,…,vn​} orthonormal
  • If the nnn columns of AAA are linearly independent, then the thin QR factorization exists.

Proof: apply the same algorithm to {a1,…,an}\{ a_{1},\dots,a_{n} \}{a1​,…,an​}, the nnn columns of AAA, and if they are all independent (when rank(A)=n\mathrm{rank}(A)=nrank(A)=n), we get orthogonal vectors qi=∑k=1iskiak,  i=1,…,nq_{i}=\sum^{i}_{k=1}s_{ki}a_{k},\,\,i=1,\dots,nqi​=k=1∑i​ski​ak​,i=1,…,nwhere the sum only goes up to iii by construction of Gram-Schmidt, since the iiith orthogonal vector only depends on the first iii of the original vectors). Furthermore, siis_{ii}sii​ is a normalizing factor to ensure unit length.
In matrix notation, Q^=AS\hat{Q}=ASQ^​=ASwhere S=(sij)S=(s_{ij})S=(sij​) is upper triangular. Its diagonal is non-zero, since the columns of AAA are independent, so it is invertible, with upper-triangular inverse R^\hat{R}R^: Q^R^=A\hat{Q}\hat{R}=AQ^​R^=A

  • Furthermore, for the full-ranked AAA, if we require the diagonal elements rii≥0r_{ii}\ge 0rii​≥0, then the QR factorization is also unique.

  • Generally, for any AAA, the thin QR factorization exists.

Proof: let rank(A)=k\mathrm{rank}(A)=krank(A)=k, then take kkk linearly independent columns, WLOG being {a1,…,ak}\{ a_{1},\dots,a_{k} \}{a1​,…,ak​}, and QR decompose it to get [↑↑a1…ak↓↓]m×k=[↑↑q1…qk↓↓]m×k[r11…r1k⋱⋮rkk]k×k\begin{bmatrix} \Bigg\uparrow & &\Bigg\uparrow \\ a_{1} & \dots & a_{k} \\ \Bigg\downarrow & & \Bigg\downarrow \end{bmatrix}_{m \times k}=\begin{bmatrix} \Bigg\uparrow & &\Bigg\uparrow \\ q_{1} & \dots & q_{k} \\ \Bigg\downarrow & & \Bigg\downarrow \end{bmatrix}_{m \times k} \begin{bmatrix} r_{11} & \dots & r_{1k}\\ & \ddots & \vdots\\ & & r_{kk} \end{bmatrix}_{k\times k}⎣⎡​⏐↑​a1​↓⏐​​…​⏐↑​ak​↓⏐​​⎦⎤​m×k​=⎣⎡​⏐↑​q1​↓⏐​​…​⏐↑​qk​↓⏐​​⎦⎤​m×k​⎣⎡​r11​​…⋱​r1k​⋮rkk​​⎦⎤​k×k​then the remaining columns {ak+1,…,an}⊂⟨a1,…,ak⟩=⟨q1,…,qk⟩\{ a_{k+1},\dots,a_{n} \} \subset \langle a_{1},\dots, a_{k} \rangle=\langle q_{1},\dots, q_{k} \rangle{ak+1​,…,an​}⊂⟨a1​,…,ak​⟩=⟨q1​,…,qk​⟩ are expressible in terms of q1,…,qkq_{1},\dots,q_{k}q1​,…,qk​, so arbitrarily extend them to an orthogonal set q1,…,qnq_{1},\dots,q_{n}q1​,…,qn​: [↑↑a1…an↓↓]=[↑↑q1…qn↓↓]m×n[r11…r1k……r1n⋱⋮⋱⋱⋮rkk……rkn0…0⋱⋮0]n×n \begin{bmatrix} \Bigg\uparrow & &\Bigg\uparrow \\ a_{1} & \dots & a_{n} \\ \Bigg\downarrow & & \Bigg\downarrow \end{bmatrix} =\begin{bmatrix} \Bigg\uparrow & &\Bigg\uparrow \\ q_{1} & \dots & q_{n} \\ \Bigg\downarrow & & \Bigg\downarrow \end{bmatrix}_{m \times n} \begin{bmatrix} r_{11} & \dots & r_{1k} & \dots & \dots & r_{1n} \\ &\ddots & \vdots & \ddots & \ddots & \vdots \\ & & r_{kk} & \dots & \dots & r_{kn} \\ & & & 0 & \dots & 0 \\ & & & & \ddots & \vdots \\ & & & & & 0 \end{bmatrix}_{n\times n}⎣⎡​⏐↑​a1​↓⏐​​…​⏐↑​an​↓⏐​​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​⏐↑​q1​↓⏐​​…​⏐↑​qn​↓⏐​​⎦⎤​m×n​⎣⎡​r11​​…⋱​r1k​⋮rkk​​…⋱…0​…⋱……⋱​r1n​⋮rkn​0⋮0​⎦⎤​n×n​where lower-right corner of RRR is empty since ak+1,…,ana_{k+1},\dots,a_{n}ak+1​,…,an​ can be expressed without qk+1,…,qnq_{k+1},\dots,q_{n}qk+1​,…,qn​. This the thin QR factorization.

  • Given a thin QR of A=Q^R^A=\hat{Q}\hat{R}A=Q^​R^, extending (the columns of) Q^\hat{Q}Q^​ to a full orthogonal basis QQQ of Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm gives the full QR of AAA.

Proof: given ai=∑jqjrija_{i}=\sum_{j}q_{j}r_{ij}ai​=∑j​qj​rij​, extending {q1,…,qn}\{ q_{1},\dots,q_{n} \}{q1​,…,qn​} to {q1,…,qm}\{ q_{1},\dots,q_{m} \}{q1​,…,qm​} does not change the coefficients–the new ones for qn+1,…,qmq_{n+1},\dots,q_{m}qn+1​,…,qm​ are all zeros. Hence this extension just adds a block of zeros under R^\hat{R}R^, which is exactly the full QR.

QR with Householder Reflections

Big idea: Householder reflections are orthogonal maps that can iteratively make AAA upper-triangular.

  • We wish to find orthogonal Q1,2,…Q_{1,2,\dots}Q1,2,…​ that eliminates elements AAA under the diagonals, column by column: AundefinedQ1[××⋯××⋯××⋯××⋯×]undefinedQ2[×  ××⋯×       ××⋯××⋯××⋯×]undefinedQ3⋯A \xrightarrow{Q_{1}}\left[\begin{array}{c|c} \times & \times \dots \times \\ & \times \dots \times \\ & \times \dots \times \\ & \times \dots \times \end{array}\right] \xrightarrow{Q_{2}} \left[\begin{array}{c|c} \times \,\, \times & \times \dots \times \\ \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\times & \times \dots \times \\ & \times \dots \times \\ & \times \dots \times \end{array}\right]\xrightarrow{Q_{3}}\cdots AQ1​​⎣⎡​×​×⋯××⋯××⋯××⋯×​⎦⎤​Q2​​⎣⎡​×××​×⋯××⋯××⋯××⋯×​⎦⎤​Q3​​⋯
  • The matrix that reflects vectors across a plane orthogonal to vvv is the Householder matrix/reflector, given by Hv=I−2vTvvvTH_{v}=I-\frac{2}{v^{T}v}vv^{T}Hv​=I−vTv2​vvTwhich is vector−2×its projection in direction of v{\text{vector}}-2 \times \text{its projection in direction of }vvector−2×its projection in direction of v.
  • Q1Q_{1}Q1​ needs to project a1a_{1}a1​, the first column of AAA, onto the first axis. Choosing v=a1−∥a1∥e1v=a_{1}-\|a_{1}\|e_{1}v=a1​−∥a1​∥e1​ gives the Householder matrix such that Hva1=∥a1∥e1=(∥a1∥,0,…,0)TH_{v}a_{1}=\|a_{1}\|e_{1}=(\|a_{1}\|,0,\dots,0)^{T}Hv​a1​=∥a1​∥e1​=(∥a1​∥,0,…,0)T
  • In general, for any u∈Rnu \in \mathbb{R}^{n}u∈Rn, there exists a Householder matrix H(w),w∈RnH(w),w \in \mathbb{R}^{n}H(w),w∈Rn that is orthogonal and Hwu=(∥u∥,0,…,0)TH_{w}u=(\|u\|,0,\dots,0)^{T}Hw​u=(∥u∥,0,…,0)T

Proof: use the same idea, with w=u−(∥u∥,0,…,0)Tw=u-(\|u\|,0,\dots,0)^{T}w=u−(∥u∥,0,…,0)T. Orthogonality is easily verified.

  • Hence successively reduce the columns of a square matrix AAA with Householder matrices give the QR decomposition.
  • Induct on the dimension of AAA, assuming that any matrix with size (n−1)×(n−1)(n-1) \times (n-1)(n−1)×(n−1) has a QR factorization. Then for A∈Rn×nA \in \mathbb{R} ^{n\times n}A∈Rn×n, find w:H(w)a1=(∥a1∥,0,…,0)Tw:H(w)a_{1}=(\|a_{1}\|,0,\dots,0)^{T}w:H(w)a1​=(∥a1​∥,0,…,0)T: H(w)A=[　∥a∥×⋯×0⋮0B　]H(w)A=\left[　\begin{array}{c|c} \|a\| & \times\dots \times \\ \hline \begin{array}{}0\\ \vdots\\ 0\end{array} & B \end{array}　\right]H(w)A=⎣⎡​　∥a∥0⋮0​​×⋯×B​​　⎦⎤​
  • Then by assumption B=Q~R~B=\tilde{Q}\tilde{R}B=Q~​R~, so [1Q~T]H(w)undefinedQTA=[1Q~T][∥a1∥×B]=[∥a1∥R~]undefinedR\underbrace{\begin{bmatrix}1 & \\& \tilde{Q}^{T}\end{bmatrix}H(w)}_{Q^{T}}A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & \\& \tilde{Q}^{T}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} \|a_{1}\| & \times \\& B\end{bmatrix}=\underbrace{\begin{bmatrix} \|a_{1}\| & \\ & \tilde{R} \end{bmatrix}}_{{R}}QT[1​Q~​T​]H(w)​​A=[1​Q~​T​][∥a1​∥​×B​]=R[∥a1​∥​R~​]​​which is the QR factorization of AAA: note that QTQ^{T}QT is orthogonal, so is QTH(w)Q^{T}H(w)QTH(w).

QR Decomposition for Linear Systems

  • It’s easy to solve the linear system Ry=zRy=zRy=z, if RRR is upper triangular, as back substitution (i.e. solving from the bottom up) is O(n2)O(n^{2})O(n2).
  • It’s also easy to solve Qy=zQy=zQy=z, if QQQ is orthogonal, as its inverse is just its transpose; multiplying them together is also O(n2)O(n^{2})O(n2).
  • Hence the QR decomposition provides an algorithm to solve the system Ax=bAx=bAx=b:

Compute the decomposition R,Q:A=QRR,Q:A=QRR,Q:A=QR.
Solve y:Ry=by:Ry=by:Ry=b where Qx=yQx=yQx=y.
Solve x:Qx=yx:Qx=yx:Qx=y.

QR Algorithm

Big idea: the QR algorithm gives an arbitrarily accurate numerical estimate of the eigenvalues.

  • The eigenvalues of a square matrix A∈Mn×n(R)A \in \mathcal{M}_{n\times n}(\mathbb{R})A∈Mn×n​(R) cannot be analytically solved when n≥5n \ge 5n≥5, according to some French guy called Galois.
  • We assume that AAA has a basis of eigenvectors viv_{i}vi​ (all unit-length), corresponding to eigenvalues λi\lambda_{i}λi​, where λ1≥λ2≥⋯≥λn\lambda_{1}\ge\lambda_{2}\ge\dots \ge\lambda_{n}λ1​≥λ2​≥⋯≥λn​.

Power Iteration

  • The power iteration is a process for finding v1v_{1}v1​, the eigenvector corresponding to λ1\lambda_{1}λ1​, the largest eigenvalue of AAA, and that λ1⪈λi≠1\lambda_{1}\gneq\lambda_{i \ne 1}λ1​⪈λi=1​.
  • Suppose λi\lambda_{i}λi​ has eigenvector v1v_{1}v1​, then starting with any vector xxx, decompose it in terms of the eigenvector-basis: x=∑i=1nαivix=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\alpha_{i}v_{i}x=i=1∑n​αi​vi​The power iteration then applies AAA successively: x↦Ax↦A2x↦…x \mapsto Ax \mapsto A^{2}x \mapsto \dotsx↦Ax↦A2x↦…which converges to be v1v_{1}v1​: Akx=Ak∑i=1nαivi=∑i=1nαiλikvi=λ1k[α1v1+∑i=2nαi(λiλ1)kviundefined→0]∝≈v1\begin{align*} A^{k}x&= A^{k}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\alpha_{i}v_{i}\\ &=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\alpha_{i}\lambda_{i}^{k}v_{i}\\ &= \lambda_{1}^{k}\left[\alpha_{1}v_{1}+ \underbrace{\sum_{i=2}^{n}\alpha_{i} \left( \frac{\lambda_{i}}{\lambda_{1}} \right)^{k} v_{i}}_{\to 0} \right]\\ &\underset{\approx}{\propto} v_{1} \end{align*}Akx​=Aki=1∑n​αi​vi​=i=1∑n​αi​λik​vi​=λ1k​⎣⎡​α1​v1​+→0i=2∑n​αi​(λ1​λi​​)kvi​​​⎦⎤​≈∝​v1​​where the quotient λi/λ1⪇1\lambda_{i} / \lambda_{1} \lneq 1λi​/λ1​⪇1 by assumption.
  • However, this algorithm is limited to one eigenvector (the one with the largest eigenvalue), and only has linear convergence by O((λ1/λ2)k)O\left((\lambda_{1} / \lambda_{2})^k\right)O((λ1​/λ2​)k), which could be slow if λ2≈λ1\lambda_{2} \approx \lambda_{1}λ2​≈λ1​.

Simultaneous Iteration

  • Although the power iteration only operates on one vector, there is nothing preventing us from applying it to multiple vectors x1,…,xsx_{1},\dots,x_{s}x1​,…,xs​: X↦AX↦A2X↦…X \mapsto AX \mapsto A^{2}X \mapsto \dotsX↦AX↦A2X↦…where x1,…,xsx_{1},\dots,x_{s}x1​,…,xs​ are the columns of XXX.

  • However, all columns of AkXA^{k}XAkX converge to something ∝v1\propto v_{1}∝v1​, so to extract more eigenvectors, we need to “remove” the components proportional to v1v_{1}v1​.

  • So making AkxiA^{k}x_{i}Akxi​ orthogonal to v1v_{1}v1​ reveals its component proportional to v2v_{2}v2​: Akx2=∑i=1nαiλikvi=λ2k[ α1(λ1λ2)kv1undefinedremoved byorthogonalization+α2v2+∑i=3nαi(λiλ2)kviundefined→0]∝≈v2\begin{align*} A^{k}x_{2}&= \sum_{i=1}^{n}\alpha_{i}\lambda_{i}^{k}v_{i} \\ &= \lambda_{2}^k \Bigg[\, \underbrace{\alpha_{1} \left(\frac{\lambda_{1}}{\lambda_{2}}\right)^{k}v_{1}}_{\substack{\text{removed by}\\\text{orthogonalization}}} + \alpha_{2}v_{2}+ \underbrace{\sum_{i=3}^{n}\alpha_{i} \left(\frac{\lambda_{i}}{\lambda_{2}}\right)^{k}v_{i}}_{\to 0} \Bigg] \\ &\underset{\approx}{\propto} v_{2} \end{align*}Akx2​​=i=1∑n​αi​λik​vi​=λ2k​[removed byorthogonalization​α1​(λ2​λ1​​)kv1​​​+α2​v2​+→0i=3∑n​αi​(λ2​λi​​)kvi​​​]≈∝​v2​​and the rate of convergence is O((λ3/λ2)k)O((\lambda_{3} / \lambda_{2})^{k})O((λ3​/λ2​)k).

  • Inductively, removing the components proportional to v1,…,vs−1v_{1},\dots,v_{s-1}v1​,…,vs−1​ in AkxiA^{k}x_{i}Akxi​ gives something proportional to vsv_{s}vs​,Akxs=∑i=1nαiλikvi=λsk[ ∑i=1s−1αi(λiλs)kviundefinedremoved byorthogonalization+αsvs+∑i=s+1nαi(λiλs)kviundefined→0]∝≈vs\begin{align*} A^{k}x_{s}&= \sum_{i=1}^{n}\alpha_{i}\lambda_{i}^{k}v_{i} \\ &= \lambda_{s}^k \Bigg[\, \underbrace{\sum_{i=1}^{s-1}\alpha_{i} \left(\frac{\lambda_{i}}{\lambda_{s}}\right)^{k}v_{i}}_{\substack{\text{removed by}\\\text{orthogonalization}}} + \alpha_{s}v_{s}+ \underbrace{\sum_{i=s+1}^{n}\alpha_{i} \left(\frac{\lambda_{i}}{\lambda_{s}}\right)^{k}v_{i}}_{\to 0} \Bigg] \\ &\underset{\approx}{\propto} v_{s} \end{align*}Akxs​​=i=1∑n​αi​λik​vi​=λsk​[removed byorthogonalization​i=1∑s−1​αi​(λs​λi​​)kvi​​​+αs​vs​+→0i=s+1∑n​αi​(λs​λi​​)kvi​​​]≈∝​vs​​assuming λi⪈λj>i\lambda_{i}\gneq\lambda_{j>i}λi​⪈λj>i​, so that the remaining terms converge to 000, then the rate of convergence is O(λi+1/λi)kO(\lambda_{i+1} / \lambda_{i})^{k}O(λi+1​/λi​)k.

  • So if we apply the Gram-Schmidt process to orthogonalize the columns AkXA^{k}XAkX, with Akxi↦qiA^{k}x_{i} \mapsto q_{i}Akxi​↦qi​,

    • When i=1i=1i=1, the power iteration gives Akx1∝≈v1A^{k}x_{1}\underset{\approx}{\propto} v_{1}Akx1​≈∝​v1​; Gram-Schmidt only rescales the first basis, so q1∝≈v1q_{1} \underset{\approx}{\propto} v_{1}q1​≈∝​v1​.
    • When i=2i=2i=2, G-S makes Akx2A^{k}x_{2}Akx2​ orthogonal to Akx1∝≈v1A^{k}x_{1}\underset{\approx}{\propto} v_{1}Akx1​≈∝​v1​, hence q2∝≈v2q_{2}\underset{\approx}{\propto} v_{2}q2​≈∝​v2​.
    • In general, AkxiA^{k}x_{i}Akxi​ is made orthgonal to v1,…,vi−1v_{1},\dots,v_{i-1}v1​,…,vi−1​, hence qs∝≈viq_{s}\underset{\approx}{\propto}v_{i}qs​≈∝​vi​.
    • Lastly, since both qiq_{i}qi​ and viv_{i}vi​ are unit vectors, qi≈±viq_{i}\approx \pm v_{i}qi​≈±vi​.{Akxi}undefinedG−S{qi}≈{±vi}\{ A^{k}x_{i} \} \xmapsto{G-S}\{ q_{i} \} \approx \{ \pm v_{i} \}{Akxi​}G−S​{qi​}≈{±vi​}

Vanilla QR Algorithm

  • The vanilla QR algorithm is straightforward: starting with A=A0A=A_{0}A=A0​, and the QR decomposition Ak=QkRkA_{k}=Q_{k}R_{k}Ak​=Qk​Rk​, the iteration is A0=Q0R011undefinedswap Q,RA1:=R0Q011undefined factorize A1=Q1R111undefinedswap Q,RA2:=R1Q111undefined factorize A2=Q2R211undefinedswap Q,R…11undefinedconvergesAk≈(╲)\begin{align*} & A_{0}=Q_{0}R_{0} \\ &\hphantom{11}\xrightarrow{\text{swap } Q,R} A_{1}:= R_{0}Q_{0}\\ &\hphantom{11}\xrightarrow{\text{ factorize }}A_{1}=Q_{1}R_{1}\\ &\hphantom{11}\xrightarrow{\text{swap } Q,R} A_{2} := R_{1}Q_{1}\\ &\hphantom{11}\xrightarrow{\text{ factorize }}A_{2}=Q_{2}R_{2}\\ &\hphantom{11}\xrightarrow{\text{swap } Q,R} \dots\\ &\hphantom{11}\xrightarrow{\text{converges}}A_{k}\approx(\diagdown) \end{align*}​A0​=Q0​R0​11swap Q,R​A1​:=R0​Q0​11 factorize ​A1​=Q1​R1​11swap Q,R​A2​:=R1​Q1​11 factorize ​A2​=Q2​R2​11swap Q,R​…11converges​Ak​≈(╲)​where the limit is diagonal since we assume AAA symmetric; otherwise it’s (⌝)(\urcorner)(┐).

  • The diagonal of AkA_{k}Ak​ gives its eigenvalues λ1,…,λn\lambda_{1},\dots,\lambda_{n}λ1​,…,λn​, which are also the eigenvalues of AAA because they are similar: Ak=Rk−1Qk−1=Qk−1−1Ak−1Qk−1=…=(Q1…Qk−1)−1A(Q1…Qk−1)=(Q(k))−1AQ(k)\begin{align*} A_{k}&= R_{k-1}Q_{k-1}\\ &= Q_{k-1}^{-1}A_{k-1}Q_{k-1}\\ &= \dots\\ &= (Q_{1}\dots Q_{k-1})^{-1}A(Q_{1}\dots Q_{k-1})\\ &= (Q^{(k)})^{-1}AQ^{(k)} \end{align*}Ak​​=Rk−1​Qk−1​=Qk−1−1​Ak−1​Qk−1​=…=(Q1​…Qk−1​)−1A(Q1​…Qk−1​)=(Q(k))−1AQ(k)​where Q(k)≡(Q1…Qk−1)Q^{(k)}\equiv(Q_{1}\dots Q_{k-1})Q(k)≡(Q1​…Qk−1​).

  • Consider the QR decomposition of Ak=Q(k)R(k)A^{k}=Q^{(k)}R^{(k)}Ak=Q(k)R(k) as a Gram-Schmidt process: denoting columns of AkA^{k}Ak as {Akei}\{ A^{k}e_{i} \}{Akei​} (eie_{i}ei​ are the columns of In×nI_{n\times n}In×n​), Q(k)R(k)=(Ake1,..,Aken)Q^{(k)}R^{(k)}=(A^{k}e_{1},..,A^{k}e_{n})Q(k)R(k)=(Ake1​,..,Aken​)so that G-S turns the columns of AkA^{k}Ak into Q(k)Q^{(k)}Q(k), an orthgonal basis.

  • As seen in the previous section, orthogonalizing the columns in AkI↦Q(k)A^{k}I \mapsto Q^{(k)}AkI↦Q(k) gives vectors converging to the eigenvectors of AAA: Q(k)=(q1(k),…,qn(k))→(v1,…,vn)Q^{(k)}=(q^{(k)}_{1},\dots,q^{(k)}_{n}) \to (v_{1},\dots,v_{n})Q(k)=(q1(k)​,…,qn(k)​)→(v1​,…,vn​)

  • Q(k)Q^{(k)}Q(k) converges to an orthogonal matrix containing eigenvectors of AAA, hence QkAk+1Qk−1=AkQ_{k}A_{k+1}Q_{k}^{-1}=A_{k}Qk​Ak+1​Qk−1​=Ak​ converges to the eigenvalue diagonalization of AAA, where the diagonal factor is Ak+1≈diag(λ1,…,λn)A_{k+1} \approx \mathrm{diag}(\lambda_{1},\dots,\lambda_{n})Ak+1​≈diag(λ1​,…,λn​)revealing the eigenvalues.

Shifts in QR Algorithm

Shifts can increase the ratios between eigenvalues, hence giving faster convergence and fewer iterations.

  • A shift of s∈Rs \in \mathbb{R}s∈R on matrix A∈Mn×n(R)A \in \mathcal{M}_{n \times n}(\mathbb{R})A∈Mn×n​(R) is the matrix A−sInA-sI_{n}A−sIn​.
    • The shift has the same eigenvectors, and has eigenvalues (λi−s)(\lambda_{i}-s)(λi​−s), where λi\lambda_{i}λi​ are the eigenvalues of AAA.
  • An iteration of the QR algorithm with shifts involves: Akundefined     shift     Ak−skIundefined factorize Ak−skI=QkRkundefinedshift backswap andAk+1:=RkQk+skI\begin{align*} A_{k} &\xrightarrow{\,\,\,\,\,\text{shift}\,\,\,\,\,}A_{k}-s_{k}I\\ &\xrightarrow{\,\text{factorize}\,} A_{k}-s_{k}I=Q_{k}R_{k} \\ &\xrightarrow[\text{shift back}]{\text{swap and}} A_{k+1}:=R_{k}Q_{k}+s_{k}I \end{align*}Ak​​shift​Ak​−sk​Ifactorize​Ak​−sk​I=Qk​Rk​swap andshift back​Ak+1​:=Rk​Qk​+sk​I​
  • With the shifted algorithm, Ak+1A_{k+1}Ak+1​ and AkA_{k}Ak​ are still similar and have the same eigenvalues: since Qk=(Ak−sI)Rk−1Q_{k}=(A_{k}-sI)R_{k}^{-1}Qk​=(Ak​−sI)Rk−1​,
    Ak+1=RkQk+sI=Rk(Ak−sI)Rk−1+sI=RkAkRk−1A_{k+1}=R_{k}Q_{k}+sI=R_{k}(A_{k}-sI)R_{k}^{-1}+sI=R_{k}A_{k}R_{k}^{-1}Ak+1​=Rk​Qk​+sI=Rk​(Ak​−sI)Rk−1​+sI=Rk​Ak​Rk−1​
  • QR with shifts potentially give fast convergence, if the shift is close to some eigenvalue: before the shift, the rates of convergence are (smaller=better): O((λi+1λi)k)without shift≫O((λi+1−sλi−s)k)with shift=O(ϵk(λi−s)k)\underset{\text{without shift}}{O\left( \left( \frac{\lambda_{i+1}}{\lambda_{i}} \right)^{k} \right)}\gg \underset{\text{with shift}}{O\left( \left( \frac{\lambda_{i+1}-s}{\lambda_{i}-s} \right)^{k} \right)}=O\left( \frac{\epsilon^{k}}{(\lambda_{i}-s)^{k}} \right)without shiftO((λi​λi+1​​)k)​≫with shiftO((λi​−sλi+1​−s​)k)​=O((λi​−s)kϵk​)if we can find s=λi+1−ϵs=\lambda_{i+1}-\epsilons=λi+1​−ϵ for some small ϵ>0\epsilon>0ϵ>0.
  • Choosing the right shift is off topic; the only shift discussed in the course is the Rayleigh quotient shift, which is the last entry of AkA_{k}Ak​: sk≡(Ak)n,n≈λns_{k}\equiv (A_{k})_{n,n} \approx \lambda_{n}sk​≡(Ak​)n,n​≈λn​It gives cubic convergence in general (non-examinable), but might fail to converge at all in some edge cases.
  • QR Algorithm with Shifts

Given AAA, set A0←AA_{0} \leftarrow AA0​←A.
While (off-diagonal has not converged): (fewer iterations!)
Set the shift sks_{k}sk​, e.g. (Ak)n,n(A_{k})_{n,n}(Ak​)n,n​
Factorize (Ak−skI)=QkRk(A_{k}-s_{k}I)=Q_{k}R_{k}(Ak​−sk​I)=Qk​Rk​
Set Ak+1=RkQk+skIA_{k+1}=R_{k}Q_{k} + s_{k}IAk+1​=Rk​Qk​+sk​I
End while, take the latest matrix AKA_{K}AK​.
Obtain eigenvalues from AK≈diag(λ1,…,λn)A_{K} \approx \mathrm{diag}(\lambda_{1}, \dots, \lambda_{n})AK​≈diag(λ1​,…,λn​), which are also the eigenvalues of AAA.

Reduction to Tridiagonal Forms

Big idea: tridiagonal matrices are cheap to do QR decomposition, so we can preprocess the matrix into a tridiagonal to make each iteration faster.

  • For a general square matrix A∈Rn×nA \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}A∈Rn×n can be reduced to its Hessenberg form/matrix with unitary similarity transformations. The Hessenberg form is almost-upper-triangular matrix with entries on the first subdiagonal: H≡Q∗AQ=[××……×××……××……×⋱⋮⋮××]H \equiv Q^{*}AQ=\begin{bmatrix} \times & \times & \dots & \dots & \times \\ \times & \times & \dots & \dots & \times \\ & \times & \dots & \dots & \times \\ & & \ddots & \vdots & \vdots \\ & & & \times & \times \end{bmatrix}H≡Q∗AQ=⎣⎡​××​×××​………⋱​………⋮×​×××⋮×​⎦⎤​
  • If A=ATA=A^{T}A=AT is symmetric, then the Hessenberg matrix of AAA is also symmetric, hence tridiagonal, and the similarity transformation involves a real, orthogonal matrix PPP such that PTAP=[××××××××⋱×××××]=HP^{T}AP=\begin{bmatrix} \times & \times \\ \times& \times & \times \\ & \times & \times & \times \\ &&&\ddots \\ &&& \times & \times & \times \\ &&&& \times & \times \\ \end{bmatrix}=HPTAP=⎣⎡​××​×××​××​×⋱×​××​××​⎦⎤​=H
  • The QR factorization of tridiagonal matrices are efficient: pre-applying (n−1)(n-1)(n−1) Givens rotations/matrices is enough.
    • The RRR matrix is an upper diagonal matrix with three non-zero diagonals.
    • Essentially, the Givens rotations move the subdiagonal to the super diagonal and the one above it.
  • A Givens rotation J(i,j)J(i,j)J(i,j) is an orthogonal matrix filled with zeros except where for some θ\thetaθ, (JiiJijJjiJjj)=(cos⁡(θ)sin⁡(θ)−sin⁡(θ)cos⁡(θ))\begin{pmatrix} J_{ii} & J_{ij} \\ J_{ji} & J_{jj} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \cos(\theta) & \sin(\theta) \\ -\sin(\theta) & \cos(\theta) \end{pmatrix}(Jii​Jji​​Jij​Jjj​​)=(cos(θ)−sin(θ)​sin(θ)cos(θ)​)and given a vector/column v=(…,ai,…,bj,… )Tv=(\dots,\underset{i}{a},\dots,\underset{j}{b},\dots)^{T}v=(…,ia​,…,jb​,…)T, ∃θ:vundefinedJθ(i,j)(…,a2+b2i,…,0j,… )T\exists\theta:v \xmapsto{J_{\theta}(i,j)}(\dots,\underset{i}{\sqrt{ a^{2}+b^{2} }},\dots,\underset{j}{0},\dots)^{T}∃θ:vJθ​(i,j)​(…,ia2+b2​​,…,j0​,…)Tand for appropriate choice of θ\thetaθ in the JJJs, the QR factorization of a triadiagonal matrix AAA is done in (n−1)(n-1)(n−1) steps: J(1,2)J(2,3)…J(n−1,n)undefinedQTA=R⟹A=QR\underbrace{J(1,2)J(2,3)\dots J(n-1,n)}_{Q^{T}}A=R \Longrightarrow A=QRQTJ(1,2)J(2,3)…J(n−1,n)​​A=R⟹A=QR
  • Pre-processing the matrix A↦HAA \mapsto H_{A}A↦HA​, its Hessenberg form, is suitable for the QR algorithm:
    • HAH_{A}HA​ is similar to AAA, hence applying QR algorithm on HAH_{A}HA​ gives the same eigenvalues.
    • If Hk=QkRkH_{k}=Q_{k}R_{k}Hk​=Qk​Rk​ is tridiagonal, so is Hk+1=RkQkH_{k+1}=R_{k}Q_{k}Hk+1​=Rk​Qk​. Hence once we reduced A0↦H0≡A_{0} \mapsto H_{0} \equivA0​↦H0​≡ Hessenberg of AAA at the start, every iteration of QR will be efficient.
  • QR Algorithm with Hessenberg Forms

Given symmetric AAA, compute H0←Hessenberg form of AH_{0} \leftarrow \text{Hessenberg form of } AH0​←Hessenberg form of A.
While (off-diagonal has not converged):
Factorize Hk=QkRkH_{k}=Q_{k}R_{k}Hk​=Qk​Rk​ (cheap!)
Set Hk+1←RkQkH_{k+1} \leftarrow R_{k}Q_{k}Hk+1​←Rk​Qk​
Obtain eigenvalues from HK≈diag(λ1,…,λn)H_{K} \approx \mathrm{diag}(\lambda_{1},\dots, \lambda_{n})HK​≈diag(λ1​,…,λn​), which are also the eigenvalues of AAA.
